awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Reward Learning Shapes the Fear Circuit
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Neuroscience research tends to conceptualize particular brain regions as specialized to encode particular types of memories. This has led to concerted efforts to locate specific memory engrams in the brain that we could eventually manipulate at will. For example, we often think about fear memories as being exclusively encoded in the brain’s “fear center”, called the amygdala. If we could locate the fear engram in the amygdala, one day we might be able to erase problematic fear memories. However, our recent work has challenged this idea of regional specialization. Specifically, we found that a brain region usually restricted to encoding rewarding memories, the hypothalamus, can be recruited to encode future fear memories if subjects have recently experienced something rewarding. Now, we will 1) investigate if this constitutes a shift away from the traditional amygdala fear circuit, 2) reveal the wider circuit that supports hypothalamic regions in the encoding of fear memories, and 3) expose whether the recruitment of hypothalamic circuits to encode fearful memories is permanent or transient. Together, this work will reveal a more fluid approach to conceptualizing memory formation in the brain. We will disseminate this knowledge to the wider community in an undergraduate seminar course while trialing the teaching philosophy “learning by observing and pitching in”, which is designed to accommodate the educational needs of the diverse student population at UCLA. Further, this project will support paid research opportunities for undergraduate students to work on the proposed experiments and prepare them for careers in scientific research.
 
We generally conceive of particular neural circuits as being specialized to encode particular types of information. However, we have recently revealed a phenomenon that calls this into question. We have shown that lateral hypothalamus (LH) can be recruited to encode fear memories, given appropriate prior experience (Sharpe et al., 2021, Nature Neuroscience). That is, LH GABAergic neurons are not necessary to encode fear memories in experimentally-naïve rodents. However, if rodents have had experience in reward learning, which is dependent on LH function, LH GABAergic neurons become critical for the encoding fear. This showed that reward learning “primes” LH to encode fear memories. We hypothesize that reward learning recruits a novel LH fear circuit to encode fear, which constitutes a shift away from the traditional amygdala circuit, in a manner that degrades with time since reward learning experience. We will use cell-type specific optogenetics and fiber photometry of a genetically-encoded calcium sensor, to investigate the causal and correlative dynamics of this phenomenon. We propose to examine: 1) if reward learning reduces the role of basolateral amygdala in encoding fear, 2) where the LH receives the necessary aversive teaching signal to encode fear memories, and 3) if increasing the delay between reward and fear procedures attenuates the involvement of LH GABAergic neurons in encoding fear. This will reveal a dynamic system that shifts between circuits that encode information depending on prior experience, which may have evolved to help us adapt to changing environments by utilizing existing cognitive schema from recent learning episodes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is strong evidence that neural circuits are specialised to encode particular types of information. This is referred to as “modularity” of brain function; some brain areas are dedicated to processing faces, while others encode speech. Similarly, it is generally accepted that we can isolate where specific types of memories are formed in the brain (i.e., the “engram”). This concept underpins much of the neuroscience research that takes place across species and assumes that where we encode memories is relatively stable across time. However, we have recently uncovered a phenomenon that calls the concept of regional specialisation into question in rats. Specifically, we found that a part of the brain thought to be restricted to forming memories about positive events (e.g., eating your favourite pizza), can become critical for encoding subsequent fearful memories (e.g. being bitten by a dog). That is, the lateral hypothalamus is not involved in encoding fear memories in naïve rats without recent positive experience. But, if rats have recently encoded a positive memory, the lateral hypothalamus suddenly becomes necessary for encoding a fearful memory. This is surprising because it suggests that a brain region not specialised for encoding a particular type of information can become critical given appropriate prior experience. This finding breaks the boundaries of regional specialization. 

 

This procedure- examining how the site for encoding fear memories changes with positive experience- acts as our case study to explore the more general phenomenon of how mnemonic encoding adapts across time. As humans have many varied experiences over their lifetime, we need to understand this process. Rats are the perfect candidate to study this phenomenon because we can control their experiences, and the neural substrates involved in fear memories overlap with humans. Indeed, foundational work in rodents examining the behavioural and neural underpinnings of fear memories have been translated to humans, which has helped develop therapeutic interventions for psychological disorders characterised by excessive fear. 

 

During the tenure of the NSF CAREER award, we set out to understand the consequences that the recruitment of the lateral hypothalamus has over the traditional neural networks that are known to encode fear memories. More specifically, the basolateral amygdala is considered the “fear centre” of the brain, necessary for forming and storing fear memories across species. This comes from a plethora of causal work in rodents and correlative work in humans. We had two hypotheses: 1) the lateral hypothalamus may engage a more distributed circuit to form fear memories, which includes the hypothalamus and amygdala, or 2) the lateral hypothalamus “takes over” as the fear centre of the brain, constituting a shift in the fear circuit away from the amygdala. Using a modern suite of neuroscience techniques across several experiments, we demonstrated that positive experience shifts the fear circuit away from the amygdala and towards lateral hypothalamus. That is, we found that the amygdala was no longer necessary for the formation or recall of fear memories after positive experience. 

 

Intellectual Merit: Current models of fear learning are amygdala-centric, supported by decades of elegant research that have implicated the amygdala as the site for the “fear engram”. We used causal tools to show that positive experience shifts the fear circuit away from amygdala and towards the lateral hypothalamus. This expands our models of fear learning and suggests caution in making conclusions about regional specialization for information encoding. 

Broader Impacts: This project contributed to the broader community in three ways. Firstly, we taught the concepts garnered from this proposal in the context of an undergraduate seminar, while trialling integration of learning by observation and pitching in (LOPI). The goal was to allow students insight into cutting-edge research, and increase inclusivity in teaching, which will help promote the engagement of people traditionally underrepresented in science into neuroscience careers. Secondly, this award expanded my mentoring role of undergraduate students in paid summer positions in my lab, which were aimed at recruiting students from HBCU and Hispanic-serving institutions, by offering additional positions to work on these experiments. This gave students from underrepresented backgrounds paid opportunities for research experience and prepare these students for graduate school. There are also important implications of this work to the general society. Specifically, this project reveals a novel hypothalamic fear circuit that is recruited to encode fear memories, which constitutes a shift away from the traditional amygdala fear circuit. This is important because we know that the degree of amygdala activity in response to fear-related stimuli predicts fear reactivity (in humans and rodent models), and this is positively correlated with fear pathology in anxiety disorders like post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Thus, the recruitment of hypothalamus to encode fear memories after experience with reward learning could be protective against pathological fear and confer resilience in the face of future adversity.
